author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea Sentences Dissident Who Fled China on a Jet Ski
description: Kwon Pyong made the 200-mile journey in August in a bid for asylum. His worst nightmare was being sent back to China, a fellow activist said.
content: After being held for months on an immigration violation, a Chinese dissident who traveled from China to South Korea on a Jet Ski-type vehicle in August was given a suspended sentence on Thursday. His prospects remain unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Rahim Fortune
title: Here’s How Houston Is Fighting Homelessness — and Winning
description: Houston demonstrates what should be obvious: that a wealthy society doesn’t have to accept as inevitable throngs of people sleeping on sidewalks.
content: Dallas and Houston are two Democratic bubbles in Texas that have long faced the familiar urban ache of homeless people slumped on sidewalks and camping in parks. Both cities tried to address the challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: As Gaza Residents Suffer, Guilt and Fear Stalk Their Families Abroad
description: “When it comes to food, when it comes to freedom,” said one Washington resident whose brother is trapped in the besieged enclave, “the feeling of guilt is killing me.”
content: Like many people around the world with families in Gaza who are anxious for news of their loved ones, wondering if they are still alive, whether they are hungry or hurt, Reem Alfranji is also consumed with guilt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A Conversation With Sam Altman, Cast in a New Light
description: Two podcast hosts recorded an interview with the chief executive of OpenAI. Two days later, he was fired.
content: In early November, a few days before a meeting of developers at OpenAI, the journalist Casey Newton bumped into Sam Altman, the company’s chief executive, at a birthday party. Mr. Altman had an idea: They should discuss “the future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell, Jeanna Smialek and Jordyn Holman
title: Retailers Worry About Shoppers’ Mood This Holiday Season
description: Consumer spending has been strong in 2023 despite higher prices and waning savings. But some retailers have jitters heading into Black Friday.
content: Christina Beck is approaching this holiday season cautiously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Sets an Immigration Record That the Tories Could Do Without
description: The governing Conservative Party has long promised to reduce arrivals. It said Brexit would help. But the numbers in 2022 were the highest ever.
content: Net legal migration into Britain climbed to almost three-quarters of a million people in 2022, official statistics showed on Thursday, a new and unwelcome record for the country’s governing Conservative Party after it promised to use its post-Brexit powers to curb the number of arrivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Long a Bastion of Liberalism, the Netherlands Takes a Sharp Right Turn
description: In an election result that sent shock waves across Europe, Geert Wilders, a longtime far-right provocateur, is closer than ever to becoming prime minister.
content: The Netherlands, long regarded as one of Europe’s most socially liberal countries, woke up to a drastically changed political landscape on Thursday after a far-right party swept national elections in a result that has reverberated throughout Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Gen Z-ers and Millennials React to ‘L.A. Law’
description: Thanks to a splashy relaunch on Hulu, new generations have their first encounter with the soapy, sax-heavy legal drama that made its debut in 1986.
content: “L.A. Law,” an Emmy-winning NBC drama that generated almost constant buzz during its run three decades ago, returned to the cultural spotlight this month when Hulu rereleased its 172 episodes in remastered high-definition format.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Labels We Attach to Political Beliefs
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about progressives and liberals. Also: Preserving forests; immigrants in New York State.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Happy Thanksgiving. Have you had a chance yet to browse our list of 100 Notable Books of 2023? Some of those books are drawn from the list below; all of them are drawn from one or another of the lists of recommended titles we bring you each week throughout the year, with an eye toward variety and quality and enlightenment or pure entertainment. This week, our recommendations include a noir crime novel, a ghost story and an Australian family drama, along with nonfiction books covering everything from a poet’s memoir of her Rastafarian childhood to a culinary history and a biography of the stalwart Republican politician Mitt Romney. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Janet Evanovich Can Laugh at Her Own Mistakes
description: As her Stephanie Plum series hits a milestone with “Dirty Thirty,” the prolific octogenarian looks back on a few bloopers.
content: Thirty books into her Stephanie Plum series, Janet Evanovich has her writing process down. She maintains two steno pads for each novel, including her latest. One, she explained in a phone interview, is where she keeps track of what her characters are up to — the pickles she wrote them into that day, how they’ll emerge when she gets back to work in the morning. The other notebook is filled with information about the trouble-attracting, doughnut-loving cast who fall in and out of love and drive like maniacs between the covers of Evanovich’s books. This is the ledger she returns to time and again, to make sure her story is consistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Mocks the Fox News Tradition of Blaming President Biden
description: “Thanks to Joe Biden’s greed, it’s even more expensive than ever to buy a raw turkey, cover it in stamps, and send it to a relative,” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Chelsea, on the Upper East Side and in Hollis Hills.
content: A two-bedroom, two-bath 1,115-square-foot apartment that has an open floor plan with under-cabinet lighting, a vented range in the kitchen, an en suite primary bathroom with radiant-heat floors and a double vanity, a washer/dryer, and zoned heating and air-conditioning, on the eighth floor of a 21-story doorman building with a concierge, a super and 12,000 square feet of amenities including an indoor pool, a gym, sauna, roof deck, playroom and bike room. John Gomes, Diana Guo and Jessica Svensson, 212-967-0215, Douglas Elliman; elliman.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Alan Feuer and Angelo Fichera
title: Johnson’s Release of Jan. 6 Video Feeds Right-Wing Conspiracy Theories
description: The speaker fulfilled a demand of the far right, which has sought thousands of hours of footage to try to rewrite the history of the Capitol attack.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson’s decision to publicly release thousands of hours of Capitol security footage from Jan. 6, 2021, has fueled a renewed effort by Republican lawmakers and far-right activists to rewrite the history of the attack that day and exonerate the pro-Trump rioters who took part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Heating Bills Hit the Hardest
description: A new study examines fuel costs, weather and other factors to find which U.S. cities are the most challenging to heat.
content: With winter looming, it’s time to brace yourself for those big heating bills. The impact on your wallet can vary depending on where you live, but a recent study may tell you how your city stacks up against others when it comes to cold-weather costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: How the Memphis Sanitation Workers’ Strike Changed the Labor Movement
description: The 1968 action led to greater economic mobility for Black workers. Today, union activists are trying to capture some of that spirit.
content: Jack Walker is a union man. He drives a garbage truck in Memphis, where his route can take him barreling past shotgun-style houses along the Mississippi River and down the narrow alleyways near the Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated. He is aware, always, of how his union protections are tied to Dr. King’s death and that of another man: his father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Rioters Clash With Police in Dublin After Children Hurt in Knife Attack
description: A suspect was in custody after a woman and three children were injured in the Irish capital. After the incident, riots that the police said were driven by “misinformation” about the attack erupted.
content: Three young children and a woman in her 30s were injured near a school in Dublin on Thursday, the police said, an attack that was followed by destructive riots that they blamed on the far right weaponizing “misinformation” about the episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Peter Coy
title: Why Is Everyone So Grumpy?
description: About the economy, that is.
content: Peter Coy: So, Binya, Americans seem very grumpy about the economy lately, despite what looks like some pretty good news. I bet a lot of people will be talking over Thanksgiving dinner about why that is. I think I have some ideas to chew on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mark Kurlansky Wishes More Authors Would Denounce War
description: “There are too many books celebrating it,” says the author, whose new book is “The Core of an Onion.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: The intricacies of a hostage deal between Israel and Hamas.
content: A temporary cease-fire paired with the releases of hostages held in Gaza and of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails is not likely to begin until tomorrow at the earliest, Israeli officials said, as negotiators continued to hammer out details of an agreement between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Turkeys Were a Marvel of Conservation. Now Their Numbers Are Dwindling.
description: Across the South and Midwest, scientists are working to understand why wild turkeys are on the decline.
content: When researchers started trapping and putting radio trackers on female turkeys in the thick woods of southeast Oklahoma, they hoped to learn how hens were successfully raising their young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Not Quite Perpendicular
description: Solving Vasu Seralathan’s puzzle, as with many Thursday crosswords, requires a different way of thinking.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yaa Addae
title: Who Are You Calling ‘Delulu’?
description: How a shorthand for delusion became popular among Gen Z-ers and young millennials.
content: Call it magical thinking or manifesting, but the belief that people can influence their reality through sheer will has existed for centuries. Now, there’s a new term for this idea: “delulu.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Deaths From Coal Pollution Have Dropped, but Emissions May be Twice as Deadly
description: Deaths linked to coal exhaust have dropped but coal exhaust is twice is likely to contribute to deaths as other air pollution, a new study found.
content: Coal, the dirtiest of fossil fuels, is far more harmful to human health than previously thought, according to a new report, which found that coal emissions are associated with double the mortality risk compared with fine airborne particles from other sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Frybread Face and Me’ Review: Reservation Summer
description: An 11-year-old boy from San Diego goes to live with his Navajo grandmother and spends time with his cousin.
content: “Frybread Face and Me” is set in 1990, when its protagonist, Benny (Keir Tallman), reluctantly goes to live on a Navajo reservation with his maternal grandmother (Sarah H. Natani). Having grown up in San Diego, the 11-year-old Benny has more experience with action figures, SeaWorld visits and Fleetwood Mac tunes than with rug weaving, sheep herding and bull riding. Over the kind of indelible summer beloved by screenwriters, he will receive an introduction to all three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cat Zhang
title: Where Can You Go to Grad School Without Going to Grad School?
description: The Brooklyn Institute for Social Research offers adult learners an education opportunity at a fraction of the time and price of graduate school.
content: Say you’re bored by your 9-to-5. You’re intellectually understimulated and you want a challenge beyond your book club, which, it turns out, is just you and your friends gossiping around a lukewarm charcuterie board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: World Peace in 2024? The Olympics Has a Plan but Not Much Hope.
description: Amid two prominent wars and other conflicts around the globe, a biennial call at the United Nations for peace during the Games felt even more symbolic than usual.
content: The president of the International Olympic Committee strode to the podium this week inside the gold-hued assembly hall of the United Nations and proceeded to paint a bleak picture of the world outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Beside Ramaswamy, a Doctor Who Listens More and Debates Less
description: Apoorva Ramaswamy, a surgeon and cancer researcher, has balanced weekdays in hospitals with weekends on the trail, with their young sons in tow.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy was holding court before a crowd at a New Hampshire fair, the second of five stops on a typically busy day of barnstorming, when he did something rare: He yielded the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Anna Foley, Elisa Gutierrez and Akilah Townsend
title: Are Black Voters Leaving Democrats Behind?
description: Polls suggest they might be. So we convened a very special Thanksgiving focus group to try and understand why.
content: The change was so remarkable that it almost seemed like a mistake: In a poll of residents in battleground states by The New York Times and Siena College this fall, 22 percent of Black voters said they would support former president Donald Trump over President Biden in a hypothetical 2024 matchup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yvon Chouinard
title: The High Stakes of Low Quality
description: The Patagonia founder Yvon Chouinard on the price we pay for cheap things.
content: Over 50 years ago, my wife, Malinda, and I bought a chef’s knife of carbon steel that we still use. It could be passed down to several generations. Compare that to the junk stainless steel ones that might not rust but that won’t hold an edge to cut a tomato.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Willie Hernández, Relief Pitcher Who Had a Banner 1984, Dies at 69
description: He was voted the American League’s Most Valuable Player and won its Cy Young Award in a championship season with the Detroit Tigers. “It’s unbelievable,” he said.
content: Willie Hernández, who won the American League’s Most Valuable Player Award in 1984 when his brilliant relief pitching helped propel the Detroit Tigers to a World Series championship, died on Monday in Sebring, Fla. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Announces Special Budget to Avert Crisis
description: Germany could be forced to suspend a constitutional law that limits borrowing, after court ruling upended Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s spending plans and threw his government into chaos.
content: Germany announced a plan to resolve a looming budget crisis on Thursday, proposing a resolution that would make it possible to fill a hole in its spending plans without requiring fresh debt. But details about the plan, which came amid growing unease about Europe’s largest economy and rising tensions within the government’s three-party governing coalition, were scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Jesse McKinley
title: After Couple’s Fatal Bridge Crash, Investigators Search for Reason
description: The explosion at the Rainbow Bridge in Niagara Falls sparked fears of terror. The car’s occupants were local residents, and the authorities said there was no threat.
content: Police investigators in Niagara Falls, N.Y., on Thursday were untangling the mystery behind why a Bentley crashed and burned at a bridge at the U.S.-Canada border, killing a local couple and causing panic on both sides on one of the year’s busiest travel days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, Who Looked at History From the Bottom Up, Dies at 94
description: He led a movement that rejected historiography’s traditional emphasis on great events and leaders in favor of mining the “mental universe” of peasants, merchants and clergymen.
content: Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, a French historian at the forefront of a scholarly movement that sought to understand the past from the bottom up, by probing the beliefs and psychology of anonymous peasants and priests rather than the exploits of triumphant generals and rulers, died on Wednesday. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our critic recommends a quirky murder show, an offbeat documentary series and a fizzy dramedy.
content: ‘Obituary’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Families Ripped Apart as Pakistan Expels Tens of Thousands of Afghans
description: Husbands and wives, parents and children, wonder when, or if, they will ever see each other again.
content: On the day Baz Gul’s world was shattered, he was out scavenging garbage with his 10-year-old son, hoping to earn a few dollars to provide for his family of five.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: Gaza Cease-Fire to Begin Today
description: Plus a surge in respiratory illnesses in China.
content: The Qatari government, which has brokered negotiations between Israel and Hamas, said a four-day pause in fighting in Gaza would begin this morning, followed by the hostage and prisoner releases. The events could lead to a significant diplomatic breakthrough in the war, now in its seventh week. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman
title: Don’t Try This on Vacation: Learning From Other Travelers’ Mistakes
description: We’ve all seen misbehavior while traveling — and some of us have even been that tourist. But every misstep can lead to a lesson, so we asked readers to share their stories.
content: Sometimes the most effective lessons sting a bit. For Nadia Caffesse, that pain came in the form of a number of tiny needles lodged in her hands, forearms and chest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousef Masoud and Daniel Victor
title: More Than 100 Bodies Are Delivered to a Mass Grave in Southern Gaza
description: In Khan Younis, 111 bodies wrapped in bright blue bags arrived in a shipping container on the back of a truck.
content: In Khan Younis, a city in the southern Gaza Strip where many Palestinians have fled to escape Israeli bombardment of the north, 111 bodies wrapped in bright blue bags arrived on Wednesday in a shipping container on the back of a truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade Draws Spectators and Protests
description: The nearly century-old holiday tradition also provided a stage for activists.
content: All along Central Park West on Thursday, throngs of people gathered for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade and packed street corners or sat on folding chairs set up since dawn. They wedged themselves on slivers of sidewalk, and some placed their toddlers atop food carts for a better view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Napierkowski and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom houses in Weston, Conn., and Bronxville, N.Y.
content: A six-bedroom, seven-full-and-two-half-bath, 9,212-square-foot home built in 1992, with a wraparound deck, an expansive foyer with inlay hardwood floors, a living room with coffered ceilings and a wood-burning fireplace, a bright dining room with built-ins, a large cook’s kitchen with a dining alcove, a family room with access to a covered porch, an en suite primary bedroom with a fireplace, two dressing rooms, a sitting room and an office, a walkout lower-level with an en suite bedroom and recreation space, a sunroom, a guest wing, an oversized three-car garage with an EV charger, a gunite in-ground pool, a stone patio with a firepit and a private dock, on 4.53 acres overlooking the Aspetuck Valley Country Club golf course. Bobbie Abagnale, 203-240-9537, William Pitt Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, williampitt.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Paul
title: How an L.A. Rams Training Complex Could Help Transform Urban Sprawl
description: The football team’s proposal for a San Fernando Valley neighborhood includes plans to create a walkable community with stores, offices and apartments.
content: The San Fernando Valley, once an endless ramble of orange groves in Southern California that evolved into the porn capital of the world in the 1970s and later gave way to big-box retailers and strip malls, will now become the home of the 2021 season’s Super Bowl champions, the Los Angeles Rams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
title: Finland Steps Up Border Closings in Dispute With Russia
description: The escalation comes as Finland tries to address a rise in the arrivals of migrants and asylum seekers that officials blame on Moscow.
content: Finland is closing all but one of its land border crossings with Russia, escalating a standoff between the two countries over an influx of migrants that Finnish officials blame on Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: India Faces Questions About Another Reported Foreign Assassination Plot
description: The U.S., while not publicly accusing New Delhi of trying to orchestrate a killing on American soil, said it had expressed concern to Indian officials.
content: For the second time in recent months, the Indian government is facing questions about whether it was involved in an assassination plot on Western soil, as American officials said they had expressed concerns to New Delhi about a thwarted plan to kill a dual U.S.-Canadian citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Fight for the Soul of A.I.
description: Now that Sam Altman’s back, will he be able to maintain a balance between safety and the profit motive?
content: One of the nice things about OpenAI is that it was built on distrust. It began as a nonprofit research lab because its founders didn’t think artificial intelligence should be pioneered by commercial firms, which are driven overwhelmingly by the profit motive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Philharmonic Feasts on ‘The Planets’
description: Under Dima Slobodeniouk, the orchestra played works by Holst and Ligeti and, for the first time, Julia Perry’s somber “Stabat Mater.”
content: Holst’s “The Planets” is one of the Thanksgiving feasts of classical music. It seduces with variety of color and texture — just as tangy cranberry compote refreshes after buttery mashed potatoes — but tends to leave you overstuffed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Former State Dept. Official Arrested in Harassing of Halal Food Vendor
description: Stuart Seldowitz was charged with harassment after videos showed him berating the vendor with Islamophobic comments.
content: The former State Department employee and national security official who was filmed harassing a halal food vendor in Manhattan and calling him a “terrorist” was arrested and charged with a hate crime on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas and OK McCausland
title: Tales of the ‘Nutcracker’ Kids
description: Siblings, a Soldier from Ukraine and a New Prince: Children are the heart of this New York City Ballet classic. We hung out with four in this year’s production.
content: School was over, but the day was not. There was the walk to her Queens apartment, the greeting and tossing into the air of Pati, the family dog, and a meal of chicken and spaghetti to eat. All the while Eliza Babinska charged along, energy spilling out of her body like sparks of electricity. She moves so fast that sometimes all you see is a mane of hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: For Jews in East Germany, a Life of Contradictions
description: An exhibition at Berlin’s Jewish Museum explores the Jewish experience in the authoritarian, and officially atheist, communist state throughout the Cold War era.
content: Just before her 14th birthday, Cathy Gelbin asked her parents for a pendant necklace with a Star of David to celebrate her “Jugendweihe,” a secular coming-of-age ceremony for German young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: Saving Praise Houses Before Their African Lineage Is Forgotten
description: The Gullah Geechee fight to preserve the tiny structures, a cradle of the Black church, before they’re erased by sprawl, climate change and fading memories.
content: The Rev. Kay Colleton will never forget the time she first laid eyes on Moving Star Hall, a tiny white clapboard building with a leaning chimney, a crooked roof and a storied history. The hall is a rare surviving example of a praise house — humble one-room structures used as places of worship by enslaved people on coastal plantations throughout the Carolinas and Georgia. They have been providing spiritual sustenance for generations of African Americans ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Smoke Sauna Sisterhood’ Review: Women, Uninterrupted
description: In Anna Hints’s bewitching documentary, Estonian smoke saunas beget a sweaty purification process — one that’s revealed to be more than skin deep.
content: In Estonia, the smoke sauna is an 800-year-old tradition carried out with regularity — to this day — by the Voro community in the southeastern part of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 23, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 23, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the 76th pre-Thanksgiving presidential turkey pardon ritual misstated when the annual tradition of a presidential turkey pardon began. While U.S. presidents have been presented with turkeys since 1947, the first documented pardon was not until 1963.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Dana Schutz Is Seriously Funny. Tracey Emin Is Seriously Honest
description: Two powerhouse female painters, both brand names, are on view in New York galleries. Compare and contrast.
content: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory? It refers to a story or a painting that comes with a moral or a lesson, perhaps a social or political one. And, in an era when figurative art has returned to prominence, the New York galleries are filled with a profusion of both allegorical paintings and their very opposite — which is to say, paintings that reject third-person narration in favor of first-person self-exposure. I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Courts Strike Down Gun Control Measures in Two States
description: The rulings in Maryland and Oregon come amid a shifting legal landscape in the wake of a Supreme Court decision that has imposed new limits on gun regulation.
content: In the wake of a landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision last year that significantly limits what the government can do to restrict guns, states led by Democrats have scrambled to circumvent or test the limits of the ruling. A few have approved new gun restrictions. Oregon even passed a ballot initiative to ban high-capacity ammunition magazines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
title: W.H.O. Asks China for Details on Surge of Respiratory Illness in Children
description: Reports of overcrowding at pediatric hospitals in China have raised concerns about a jump in respiratory illnesses affecting children.
content: The World Health Organization has formally requested that China share detailed information about a recent increase in respiratory illnesses, citing unconfirmed media reports of undiagnosed pneumonia in children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Lauren Hirsch
title: In Biden’s Climate Law, a Boon for Green Energy, and Wall Street
description: The law has effectively created a new marketplace that helps smaller companies gain access to funding, with banks taking a cut.
content: The 2022 climate law has accelerated investments in clean-energy projects across the United States. It has also delivered financial windfalls for big banks, lawyers, insurance companies and start-up financial firms by creating an expansive new market in green tax credits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Thanksgiving Pep Talk
description: Every little thing is going to be all right.
content: Good morning. You taking care of yourself? Getting some “me” time? I don’t write much about feelings, generally, but this is a day that can be thick with them: judgy siblings; over-served cousins; ungrateful offspring; that silent stranger who arrived with your aunt and who might be her boyfriend, it’s hard to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: Israel Releases Videos It Says Show Hamas Tunnels Under Al-Shifa Hospital
description: Israeli and American officials have said that Hamas uses hospitals for cover. Hamas and administrators of Al-Shifa, Gaza’s largest hospital, have denied the claims.
content: The Israeli military sought on Wednesday to bolster its assertions that Hamas uses tunnels beneath Gaza’s largest hospital, releasing a series of videos that it said showed “dozens of meters of a tunnel system” beneath the complex of Al-Shifa Hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A New Way of Harvesting Organs Divides Doctors and Ethicists
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 23, 2023.
content: “It’s kind of a creepy thing to be doing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The 25 Things I’m Thankful for in American Politics
description: Or 26, if you count not sharing the stuffing with George Santos.
content: Ah, Thanksgiving. That magical time when friends and family gather round the table to share the love, reminisce — and bicker endlessly about politics and the state of the nation. If your clan is anything like mine, the conversation bends toward the grim and angsty: President Biden’s advanced age, Donald Trump’s legal dramas, Ron DeSantis’s creepy robot smile, the price of Tom Turkey, the chaos in Congress, the government’s alien cover-up …. It can be a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: You Know About Rockefeller Center’s Tree. Here’s Where to Eat Nearby.
description: From sit-down meals to sandwiches and pizza, this is the best food in and under the plaza.
content: As a local, I ought to hate anything in New York that draws a crowd. In theory, this includes the tree at Rockefeller Center. Once the tree’s lights are switched on — this year, that first happens Wednesday night, just before 10 p.m. — the plaza becomes an unholy gridlocked mob of sightseers, shoppers and commuters. It stays that way until Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: White House Eyes Possible Threat to Good Friday Agreement: Rwanda
description: Biden administration officials are watching whether the British government’s attempt to salvage its Rwanda asylum policy risks undermining the Northern Ireland peace accord.
content: The British government’s effort to salvage its contentious policy of deporting asylum seekers to Rwanda is drawing attention from the White House, which wants to make sure any revamped legislation does not undermine the Good Friday Agreement in Northern Ireland, according to two Biden administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks, Shannon Busta and Derek Arthur
title: David Brooks on Staying Humane in Inhumane Times
description: The ancient wisdom of Athens and Jerusalem can help us survive these cruel and challenging times.
content: These are cruel and challenging times. How did previous generations hold on to their sanity — and humanity — in the face of violence and instability?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Against the Tide’ Review: Tales of the Sea
description: Sarvnik Kaur’s breathtaking documentary about Indigenous fishermen in Mumbai brings to life an ecosystem wrecked by corporate greed and climate change.
content: “Against the Tide, ” Sarvnik Kaur’s breathtaking documentary about Indigenous fishermen in Mumbai, India, dispels the myth that cinematic beauty has to do with the power of the camera or the glossiness of the image. Shot by Ashok Meena, the film finds beauty, simply, in perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Suzanne Shepherd, Actress Known for Playing Mothers, Dies at 89
description: After establishing herself as a teacher, she started a prolific screen acting career in her 50s that included roles in “Goodfellas” and “The Sopranos.”
content: Suzanne Shepherd, an influential New York acting teacher who found success in midlife as a character actress, including memorable turns as the mothers of Edie Falco’s character on “The Sopranos” and Lorraine Bracco’s character in “Goodfellas,” died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: The Certainties of a Putin Election Meet the Uncertainties of War
description: There is little doubt about the outcome, should he run, but the election in March carries more significance as the first one since the invasion of Ukraine.
content: When asked last week what kind of leader should replace President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, his longtime spokesman gave a quick and simple answer: “the same.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dayton Duncan
title: Why We Should Bring Back the Buffalo
description: Efforts to bring these animals back to America can be a much-needed redemptive act of healing.
content: In 1805, when the Lewis and Clark expedition reached the border of what is now North Dakota and Montana, they found herds of American buffalo so numerous, “the whole face of the country was covered” by them, Meriwether Lewis wrote. Less than a century later, in 1889, the nation’s most majestic animal (whose scientific name is Bison bison) had been reduced from practically uncountable numbers to an easily countable 541, and the species teetered on the edge of extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: With Israel at War, Thanksgiving Is Fraught for Some Jewish Families
description: Even families that are used to arguing over dinner are feeling new tension this year, as members from different generations disagree about supporting Israel.
content: There will be turkey at Marci Rosa’s family Thanksgiving in New Jersey, and stuffing and sweet potato and leek gratin. But also kasha varnishkes, a Jewish grain dish with roots in Eastern Europe, where her in-laws survived the Holocaust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: He Lived a Frugal Life. Then He Left Millions to His New Hampshire Town.
description: When Geoffrey Holt died in June, his will revealed a secret: He had $3.8 million, and he was leaving all of it to the town of Hinsdale, where he had been living quietly in a trailer park.
content: Geoffrey Holt, the caretaker of a mobile home park in Hinsdale, N.H., did little to stand out and mostly kept to himself, at least as far as Kathryn Lynch, the town administrator, knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Lawsuit Accuses Eric Adams of Sexual Abuse Three Decades Ago
description: The mayor denied the accusation and said he has never met the Florida woman who filed the case under the Adult Survivors Act.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York has been accused in a lawsuit filed under New York’s Adult Survivors Act of sexually assaulting a Florida woman three decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Families in the West Bank Eagerly Await a Prisoner Release
description: The announcement that an exchange of hostages for prisoners would begin on Friday lifted the hopes of many Palestinians whose relatives are in Israeli jails.
content: As soon as the Tanji siblings heard that their youngest sister, Walaa, could be released from an Israeli prison on Thursday, they began frantically preparing for her arrival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Charleston Elects Republican Mayor for First Time Since 1870s
description: The new mayor, William Cogswell, said partisan politics took a back seat to “mutual love and respect” for the South Carolina city.
content: The city of Charleston this week elected a Republican mayor for the first time since the mid-1870s, signifying a new chapter for the centuries-old southern city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: You Deserve a Great Nap
description: Experts say a midday rest is great for your health. Here’s how to get the most out of it.
content: You can’t beat coffee for a morning pick-me-up, but as the day wears on, energy levels can slump. To regain your momentum, should you reach for that third latte? Or push through and hope you perk up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Joss Ackland, Busy, Versatile Actor on Stage and Screen, Dies at 95
description: He was a villain in “Lethal Weapon 2,” C.S. Lewis on TV in “Shadowlands” and Falstaff onstage in “Henry IV” — and had a cameo in a Pet Shop Boys video.
content: Joss Ackland, a self-described workaholic actor who appeared in more than 130 movies, TV shows and radio programs, most notably — for American audiences, at least — as a villainous South African diplomat in “Lethal Weapon 2,” died on Sunday at his home in Clovelly, a village in southwestern England. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Torrential Rain and Floods Wreak Havoc Across East Africa
description: The deluges have caused deaths and displacement in a region still reeling from its worst drought in four decades.
content: Heavy rains and floods have killed scores of people and displaced hundreds of thousands of others across eastern Africa in recent weeks, governments and the United Nations said, underscoring the intensifying climatic hazards in a politically and economically tumultuous region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Aaron Boxerman and Isabel Kershner
title: Here’s What We Know About the Israel-Hamas Deal
description: Officials in Qatar, which helped broker the deal, said 13 hostages were expected to be released on Friday. An Israeli official said Palestinians in Israel’s custody would be freed first.
content: A deal between Israel and Hamas for a temporary cease-fire is expected to go into effect on Friday. Here is a closer look at the agreement, mediated in part by Qatar, and how it is expected to play out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Corey Schreppel and Dan Powell
title: (Yet Another) Emergency Pod: Sam Altman Is Back
description: Fired, then hired to the same post.
content: In yet another head-spinning twist at OpenAI, Sam Altman was reinstated as the company’s chief executive on Tuesday night, a mere five days after the OpenAI board had fired him. The board will be overhauled and a new set of directors, including Bret Taylor and Lawrence Summers, will join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Happy Thanksgiving
description: Today is about accepting things as they are, not as you wish them to be, and you’re going to serve a wonderful meal.
content: Good morning. You taking care of yourself? Getting some “me” time? I don’t talk too much about feelings in this newsletter, but this is a day that can be thick with them: judgy siblings, over-served cousins, ungrateful offspring; that silent stranger who arrived with your aunt and who might be her boyfriend, it’s hard to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: On Thanksgiving, Can Biden’s Family Talk Turkey?
description: With the 2024 election drawing nearer, there are crucial questions to ask.
content: Peaks are lonely places. They don’t accommodate crowds. And Joe Biden, at the pinnacle of American politics, is to some degree isolated, as all presidents wind up being. Not many people have real, meaningful access to him. Not many voices break through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: He Wanted a Studio in Lower Manhattan for Less Than $450,000. But Where?
description: Rather than accept a rent increase, a downtown denizen went looking for a studio he could afford to buy. In the end, he discovered, it all ‘comes down to neighborhood.’
content: Rather than accept a rent increase, a downtown denizen went looking for a studio he could afford to buy. In the end, he discovered, it all ‘comes down to neighborhood.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Malkin
title: 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico
description: Make mole, learn printmaking and dance in the streets in this city alive with tradition and creative vigor.
content: Make mole, learn printmaking and dance in the streets in this city alive with tradition and creative vigor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By U.S. Customs and Border Protection and Reuters
title: Footage Shows Car in Midair Before Rainbow Bridge Explosion
description: Footage released by U.S. Customs and Border Protection showed a vehicle speeding and taking off into the air before an explosion at a U.S.-Canada border crossing.
content: Footage released by U.S. Customs and Border Protection showed a vehicle speeding and taking off into the air before an explosion at a U.S.-Canada border crossing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Chinese Hospital Overloaded as Child Respiratory Illnesses Surge
description: Families crowded the waiting room and registration area of Capital Institute of Pediatrics, a hospital in Beijing, with respiratory illnesses in children increasing in the country.
content: Families crowded the waiting room and registration area of Capital Institute of Pediatrics, a hospital in Beijing, with respiratory illnesses in children increasing in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Riots in Dublin After Knife Attack Injures 3 Children and a Woman
description: People set police cars on fire in riots after a knife attack near a school in Dublin. The police blamed a far-right faction for the unrest and suggested the rioters were driven by “misinformation” about the attack.
content: People set police cars on fire in riots after a knife attack near a school in Dublin. The police blamed a far-right faction for the unrest and suggested the rioters were driven by “misinformation” about the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Deadly Landslide Hits Alaska Community
description: An aerial view of the landslide showed its path down a mountain in Wrangell, in southeast Alaska.
content: An aerial view of the landslide showed its path down a mountain in Wrangell, in southeast Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times
